instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2532: What is 820-2532? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2532</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Intermittent no power issue
threads.message: So on the bench I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2532</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with a strange issue. It is usually drawing 40mA and not powering on, so I checked power rails and am missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>. I removed L7220 and injected 5v to mimmic the 5v rail coming from <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and then triggered <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and the board started. I removed the wires and put L7220 back on, try it again and the board fired up. Well after the board cooled off, it would no longer start, so I back to square one. I took my heat gun and heated the areas again and lo and behold it started again. I'm beginning to suspect a bad cap.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2532</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Intermittent no power issue
threads.message: I believe this board is one of the ones prone to the classic <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> failures. I'm getting 330ohms to GND but do not have another board for reference.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2532</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Intermittent no power issue
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2532</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Intermittent no power issue
threads.message: Thank you piernov. I replaced <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> and it seems to be working well. I let it cool for an hour and it still turns on. Just out of curiosity, are there any measurements that can be done to confirm this is a fix either way? I understand that the proof is the computer is now running, I was thinking about for the sake of being able to measure something.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2532</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Intermittent no power issue
threads.message:
You should check L7770 voltage before replaced it.
Bad <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> usually causes 0.3V there.
That is 100% confirmation...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2532</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Intermittent no power issue
threads.message: Is that before triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>? If so, I measured .33V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2532</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - Intermittent no power issue
threads.message: Then the board shouldn't have another problem; after changing <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>.
